Content.BodyCopy:
Outcome 1: Recognition and appreciation. Students with a Creative Writing Emphasis in the English major at BYU-Idaho and are able to recognize basic genre distinctions of fiction, poetry, creative non-fiction, and drama. They also can appreciate and articulate characteristics of quality in creative writing they encounter.
Evidence of Learning: Direct Measure
  • Creative writing students at BYU-Idaho are regularly assigned to read exemplary works of creative writing and to show their knowledge of and appreciation for standards of literary quality in discussions conducted in small groups and before the entire class.
  • Creative writing students are regularly assigned to write responses to fiction, poetry, and other genres of literature that analyze and comment on characteristics of quality creative writing.
Evidence of Learning: Indirect Measure
The evidence suggests that . . .
Outcome 2: Writing Ability. BYU-Idaho creative writing students are able to write original works of fiction, poetry, creative non-fiction, drama, and/or other genres that satisfy genre conventions and express personal and universal matters in a literary style.
Evidence of Learning: Direct Measure
  • Works produced by creative writing students are regularly assessed by teachers in both classroom and one-on-one teacher conference settings in which teachers judge student work by clearly communicated standards and offer suggestions for revision.
  • All creative writing courses at BYU-Idaho involve some degree of “workshop” instruction in which students share their work with each other in small groups and critique the work of their peers.
  • Each semester, the BYU-Idaho English Department sponsors a Student Writing Retreat. Selected students spend three days together with creative writing faculty in an off-campus university facility in a beautiful mountain setting.
Evidence of Learning: Indirect Measure
The evidence suggests that . . .

Publishing Knowledge. Creative writing students understand the principles and practices of contemporary creative publishing and have opportunities to submit their own writing for publication and presentation.
Evidence of Learning: Direct Measure
  • In English 418, Creative Writing and Publishing, students learn about contemporary creative publishing and submit their own work for publication in a literary journal of their choice.
  • Indicator: Each semester students in English 418, Creative Writing and Publishing, act as the student editorial board for Outlet, the BYU-Idaho student literary journal. In this capacity, they select submissions, work with authors on revisions, and work with graphic design students on matters of layout and presentation.
  • Indicator: Creative writing students submit their writing to the College of Language and Letters Pre-Professional Conference, which allows selected participants to present their work in an on-campus conference setting.
Evidence of Learning: Indirect Measure
